LineComment.val: -- We begin by declaring the compression operations we will use
-- and also a convenient shorthand for sharing and hiding
-- A buffer from 'in' to 'out' restricted to values in 'type'
-- and non-deterministically holding at most 'n' values.
-- A buffer, as above, but which is allowed to drop up to (but not
-- including) 'PassRate' consecutive values.

BlockComment.val:
{----------------------------------------------------------------------- Specification of Connection Service
Packets of data (type Connection_Data) are to be transmitted between hosts according to connections defined by ports at each end. -}

LineComment.val: -- Instance data: how this particular network is wired up

BlockComment.val: {- The specification for the connection is that each source/destination pair which are specified by Connections show behave like a one-place buffer. -}

{----------------------------------------------------------------------- Refinement 1
Connection service implemented on top of a network service which provides unsynchronized transmission between host.port pairs. -}

LineComment.val: --hostof(h.p) = h -- dot-pattern not supported at the moment

BlockComment.val: {- The specification for the network service is that it provides reliable bidirectional communication, but may introduce buffering. -}

{- Given a network layer which is at least as good as NetworkService, we can build a connection layer which is as good as the required ConnectionService. We do this by masking the buffering introduced by the network using an explicit acknowledgement. Each output port between the connection and network layer needs to wait for the acknowledgement inserted by the corresponding input port. -}

{----------------------------------------------------------------------- Refinement 2
Implementing the network layer on top of a transport layer by multiplexing. -}

LineComment.val: -- Transport packets are labelled with destination addresses
-- Transport Service Spec
-- Multiplexer Definitions
-- within ||| h : Host @ NetworkTransmitter(h) ||| NetworkReceiver(h)
-- precedences in FDR are unconsistent
-- we have to use Parenteses here
-- Subject to establishing suitable buffering constraints, we could prove
-- C[NetworkService] [F= C[NetworkLayer}
-- for a context C[ ]
-- The Connection Layer is, in fact such a context:

BlockComment.val:
{----------------------------------------------------------------------- Refinement 3
Implement transport service on top of two pairs of potentially unreliable channels, using the alternating bit protocol. -}

{- Given suitable constraints on the buffering and network capacity (which we might represent as a context C[ ], we would be able to show C[NetworkService] [F= C[NetworkLayer2]
Indeed the following result is an example of this: -}

{- If we introduce a deliberate fault into the transport service, then the implementations of the network and connection layers may no longer good enough ... if we attempt to use them, we could fail to be as good as ConnectionService. -}
